intro: Gagea pinardii var. filifolia, commonly known as the filifoliate gagea, is a rare and delicate perennial bulbous plant native to the mountainous regions of southwestern China. It belongs to the Amaryllidaceae family and is characterized by its slender, grass-like leaves and small, bell-shaped flowers that bloom in early spring. The plant produces a cluster of narrow, thread-like leaves, giving it its varietal name "filifolia," which translates to "thread-leaved." It thrives in cool, moist, and well-drained soils, often found in forested or rocky habitats. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a species of conservation concern.
